awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The constraints of dual morphological systems on visual word processing in Maltese
awd_abstract_narration:
All languages have strategies for combining independently meaningful linguistic units, called morphemes, to build words. Most languages, like English, primarily combine these units by linearly appending them to one another (e.g. re- + write -> rewrite); such languages are said to have linear morphology. Semitic languages, like Arabic, are famous for having nonlinear morphology: discontinuous units which express meaning and grammatical information are combined non-linearly (e.g. Arabic k-t-b 'writing' + aa-i 'doer, NOUN' -> kaatib 'author'). Maltese is particularly unusual in its morphological characteristics: as a Semitic language, Maltese has primarily used non-linear morphology historically. However, for the past millennium it has been in close contact with a series of languages that use linear morphology (Sicilian, Italian, French, and English), and speakers have heavily borrowed words and adopted linear morphological strategies from these languages. Today, Maltese comprises a "mixed" language: at least half of all words are borrowed from non-Semitic languages (and so do not exhibit non-linear morphology), and speakers use both linear and non-linear word-building strategies extensively. This project investigates how the presence of distinct morphological systems in Maltese affects word processing, exploring differences in how Maltese readers recognize Semitic words vs. non-Semitic borrowings. It explores the impact of historical language mixing on the processes underlying daily language use, and so has implications for the study of languages in similar contact situations. The results of a series of experiments will comprise the data analyzed in the Co-PI's dissertation. The project will also produce a database of Maltese word recognition data, the first such database for a language with non-linear morphology, which other researchers may use to study language processing.

The Co-PI, a doctoral student at the University of Arizona, will conduct a series of psycholinguistic experiments investigating how the existence of distinct lexicons exhibiting unique morphological characteristics (native Semitic words vs. non-Semitic borrowings) affects visual word recognition in Maltese. Previous research has found (1) that Maltese readers are faster to recognize Semitic words than non-Semitic borrowings and (2) that, when primed by letter strings consisting of a subset of a word?s consonants (e.g. frx primes FIREX 'to spread'), they are faster to recognize Semitic words (for which such strings comprise a morpheme) but not non-Semitic ones (for which such strings are non-morphemic). The latter finding conflicts with the "subset priming" effect found in non-Semitic languages, namely that exposure to such letter strings typically facilitates word recognition (e.g. 'csn' primes CASINO), owing to the role of consonant letters in constraining lexical candidates, and suggests that language-specific morphological properties such as Semitic nonconcatenative morphology may further shape the role of consonant letters in lexical processing. The proposed research includes (1) a Maltese visual lexical decision megastudy which explores processing differences between Semitic and non-Semitic words across a wide range of items when potential confounding factors like orthographic neighborhood density and morphological structure are controlled for (and which will result in the publication of a database of Maltese lexical decision responses) (Experiment 1); and (2) a series of visual masked priming studies which test for subset priming effects in non-Semitic Maltese words when confounding factors, namely the morphemic status of the prime, are controlled for (Experiments 2-3).

por.por_cntn:
The co-PI conducted a series of linguistics experiments with speakers of Maltese, assessing how they recognize written Maltese words and differentiate them from nonce words. Maltese is a Semitic language that is closely related to Arabic, having originated as a dialect of Arabic which borrowed approximately half of its lexicon from the unrelated languages Sicilian, Italian, and English over the last millennium, and the presence of Arabic- and non-Arabic-origin words in Maltese poses novel challenges for word recognition among Maltese speakers.

Through this project, the co-PI built a database of Maltese word recognition data which may be used to study word recognition in Maltese. The database comprises approximately 237,000 behavioral responses to ~11,000 Maltese words and ~11,000 Maltese-like nonce words provided by 104 native Maltese speakers who participated in the series of experiments, making the database significantly larger and more diverse in terms of stimuli and participants than the datasets produced in standard linguistics experiments. Similar databases exist for English, Dutch, French, and a handful of other languages, but none for any Semitic language nor for any language with a history of word-borrowing similar to that of Maltese, making this a unique database.

The co-PI has prepared and analyzed subsets of the final dataset in order to study how typical linguistic variables (e.g. the frequency with which speakers have been exposed to a given word) affect word recognition in Maltese, and in particular how these effects differ for Arabic-origin vs. non-Arabic-origin Maltese words and for real words vs. nonce words. The co-PI has presented the results of preliminary analyses at the 33rd Annual CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing in Spring 2020, and the results of this project will form the core of his PhD dissertation. The co-PI will make the database available to other researchers, who may study how other linguistic and non-linguistic variables impact word recognition in Maltese or use it for other purposes (e.g. to computationally model language processing in Maltese).
